name: Venmo
description: Paying with a cell phone is a foreign experience to most people. Further, user’s tolerance for confusion in financial services is especially low. It was critical that users trust Venmo immediately. We designed product features and communication to evoke trust and build a sense of Venmo "community". Expect the new app with these changes to be launched soon!

name: MoveTogether
description: Ridesharing is a difficult two-sided, supply-driven market problem. It's hard to incentivize drivers to offer a ride as they prize convenience and their quiet, personal time. However, ridesharing was more successful amongst close-knit communities. Therefore, my team pivoted to a one-sided market: taxi-sharing amongst the business community. We prototyped at the GoogleI/0 conference in 2011, matching rides to and from SFO. It was a big success.

name: Yiftee
description: Small business owners are incredibly busy and have difficult-to-integrate POSs. They do not have time to analyze rich customer data or train employees on new offerings. Their bottom-line is their major concern. Therefore, my team pivoted from an initial customer data product to a digital gift-giving service that was much lower touch and had a more direct impact on revenue. Check out Yiftee!

name: National Grocery Chain
description: Designed and conducted a consumer research program consisting of an online survey, customer interviews, shop-alongs and focus groups to improve the pharmacy/grocery experience.

name: Global Pharmaceutical
description: Helped implement a pilot program for an alternative revenue model for a pharmaceutical company based on preventative care and education. Collaborated closely with the client to develop training materials and conduct workshops to train new product ambassadors.

name: Canadian Teleco
description: A regional Canadian Telco was looking to expand nationally. We assessed user needs and the potential economic viability of various segments - the chinese immigrant population, college students, cab drivers and the elderly. For each segment, we prototyped relevant product features based on user research, and presented ideas to leadership for implementation.

name: Sigma-Dek
description: People desire the emotional satisfaction of building a deck themselves instead of contracting it out. But they want to be able to build the deck in a weekend and without many obscure tools. Therefore, the team prototyped (and eventually built) a simple snap-in-place deck kit. Pieces snap together, but are still stable, safe and strong, and the entire deck can be built in 45 minutes. It's now sold across North America.

name: Marketing White Paper
description: A re-look on the traditional advertising mantra: market, media, message. Effective global brands, also consider "moment". When are users most inclined to be receptive, and how can you create in-store experiences that make emotional connections with your customers. My team wrote a white paper the importance of moment and good examples of the 4Ms.

name: Legal Services Company
description: An emerging trend at the time was the use of semantic-based search for the discovery process. Semantic-based search yields results based on meaning, rather than simple text matching, so you can find more relevant results. We recommended that our client enter this space through an acquisition and shunt resources to this area.

name: Gmail Analysis
description: We spend so much of our time and interaction on email now! I wrote an R package that downloads a user's email history, conducts text analysis and graphs results. What time of day are you most likely to reply to an email? What day of week? How many emails do you send per day?

name: SplitMyRide
description: Wrote all server-side code for a taxi-sharing service that matches people taking cabs from New York airports to Manhattan / Brooklyn.

name: Instagram Challenge
description: Totally got addicted to this instagram engineering challenge. Task: Fix a shredded and scrambled image.

name: Venmo
description: Picked up android programming as it was a high need at the time for the start-up.

name: Search Algorithm
description: A comparison of the efficiency of two different search methods for searching through a body of documents: term-at-a-time and document-at-a-time. Term-at-a-time is optimal for shorter, rare query terms, while doc-at-a-time is preferred for longer and more frequent queries.

name: DrinksOnMe
description: A foursquare-venmo mash-up that allows you to buy a drink (on Venmo) for anyone checked-in to the same location as you (on foursquare). Basically a pick-up tool for the shy geek in some of us.

name: pod
description: Pulls and displays photos from a flickr account that were taken on today's date in any previous year.

name: National Cable Provider
description: In the past, decisions at this company had largely been driven by instinct and intuition of leadership. With the changing landscape in media, the company needed to better understand their customers and product lines in a quantitative way. Therefore, my team developed a customer-life-time value model to identify high-profit and low-profit customers, which customers are worth trying to keep, and what product lines are associated with lowest churn.

name: Global Pharmaceutical
description: Built a war-game simulation model for a client's new drug. The model forecasted 36 month profits under various indication scenarios and various competitor launch scenarios.

name: YogaProject
description: I made this series of yoga videos for friends in Asia, where unfortunately good yoga classes are not readily available.

name: Mzcombozi Secondary
description: Taught 8th grade math to 40 students who sat in 20 desks. The thrill of seeing their faces when a concept clicked is still one of the greatest moments in my life. I had to do a lot of laundry during those 5 weeks because I typically came home covered in chalk dust.

name: CatchPhrase
description: First arduino hack. User presses a button to prompt a new random phrase from a previously programmed list. Word is displayed on an LCD screen. Good for charades and studying.

name: Splash
description: Taught kids in East Palo Alto, an hour long seminar on "Things I wish I learned when I was your age". Topics included how to make decisions, how to deal with feedback in work and relationships, and an introduction to cognitive heuristics we all have to watch out for.
